practice tends to be that a judge must then
face a "retention" election. I will describe

3727.45.text:
the practice in the state with which I am
most familiar, that is California. According

3733.41.text:
to the constitution of the State of California,
judges for the Supreme Court must be nominated

3738.08.text:
by the Governor and confirmed by the Commission
on Judicial Appointments, which consists of

3744.02.text:
the Chief Justice, the Attorney General, and
the Presiding Justice of the Court of Appeals.

3750.42.text:
Since 1979 it has been required that the State
Bar commission on judicial nominees' evaluation

3757.07.text:
should conduct a thorough investigation of
the background and qualifications of prospective

3762.14.text:
nominees. However, the Governor is not bound
by that commission's recommendations. Once

3769.90.text:
appointed, judges must stand for retention
at the time of the next gubernatorial election

3775.91.text:
after their appointment. Appellate judges
serve twelve year terms. Although, in many

3782.93.text:
states, judicial retention elections are low
key affairs, in the state of California they

3788.14.text:
have often been controversial. I remember
that, while I was a student in California

3793.86.text:
in 1986, there was a well organised campaign
against some members of the state Supreme

3799.68.text:
Court, including the Chief Justice, Rose Elizabeth
Bird. The particular reason why they were

3807.14.text:
unpopular with many electors was their perceived
antipathy to use of the death penalty. A total

3814.30.text:
of $11.5 million was spent on campaigning
both for and against the judges, setting what

3821.64.text:
was at that time a record for spending in
a judicial election. They were voted off the

3830.42.text:
In this country, of course, we have no election
for judges, not even what the Americans call

3835.58.text:
a "retention" election. There was a time,
around the turn of the 19th and 20th centuries,

3843.08.text:
when Lord Halsbury was Lord Chancellor in
the Salisbury governments, when party affiliation

3848.73.text:
does appear to have played a part in judicial
appointments. However, that has long since

3855.23.text:
passed. In any event, today we have the Judicial
Appointments Commission (in England and Wales).

3863.27.text:
That commission was created by Parliament
in the Constitutional Reform Act 2005, with

3869.09.text:
the express purpose of placing it at arm's
length from the government of the day. There

3874.59.text:
are similar appointment bodies in Scotland
and Northern Ireland. When it comes to the

3880.82.text:
Supreme Court of the UK, appointees are selected
by a panel which includes representatives

3887.55.text:
of the JAC and its counterparts in the other
parts of the UK. The sole criterion for judicial

3896.34.text:
appointments is merit: that is now a statutory
requirement in the 2005 Act.

3905.37.text:
In the past it was not uncommon for judges
in this country to have had party political

3910.87.text:
careers. Some of our best judges had such
a background:36 for example, Lord Reid, who

3929.25.text:
served with great distinction on our highest
court, the House of Lords, between 1949 and

3935.21.text:
1975, had been a Conservative MP. Another
Law Lord, Lord Simon of Glaisdale, was appointed

3942.69.text:
straight to become President of the old Probate,
Admiralty and Divorce Division of the High

3947.74.text:
Court in 1962. Before his appointment he was
a Conservative MP and Solicitor General in

3954.35.text:
Harold Macmillan's government. There was until
well into the 20th century a practice by which,

3961.26.text:
if the post of Lord Chief Justice became vacant,
the Attorney General of the day had the right

3968.31.text:
Sir Rufus Isaacs became Lord Reading CJ in
that way, having been a Liberal MP and a member

3974.17.text:
of the Asquith Government. Indeed our modern
sensibilities about the separation of powers

3979.57.text:
may be quite recent. While Lord Reading was
a serving Chief Justice, he was also appointed

3986.88.text:
to be this country's ambassador to the United
States. The last such appointment was that

3993.88.text:
of Lord Hewart CJ, who had been a Conservative
MP and Attorney General in the National government

4001.29.text:
In the United States, one former President
became Chief Justice of the US Supreme Court

4007.74.text:
(William Howard Taft). One of the most successful
Chief Justices in American history, Earl Warren,

4013.19.text:
had been a Republican Governor of California
and only just lost out to Eisenhower for the

4018.83.text:
Republican nomination for the presidency in
1952. It is often reported that, when President

4024.91.text:
Eisenhower left the White House, he was asked
whether he had made any mistakes during his

4029.85.text:
presidency. He replied "only two: and they
are both sitting on the Supreme Court." He

4036.12.text:
was thinking of Chief Justice Warren and Justice
Brennan.

4040.30.text:
There can be no doubt that some great American
judges have previously held high political

4046.61.text:
office. For example Justice Robert Jackson
had been Attorney General in the administration

4051.60.text:
of President Franklin Roosevelt and served
with great distinction both on the US Supreme

4056.88.text:
Court and as the Chief Prosecutor at the Nueremberg
War Crimes Tribunal after the Second World

4063.68.text:
War. More recently, one of the current justices
of the Supreme Court, Elena Kegan, was Solicitor

4070.03.text:
General in President Obama's administration,
having previously been Dean of Harvard law

4077.20.text:
In this country also we have experience of
such appointments, indeed quite recently.

4082.95.text:
Lord Mackay of Clashfern was a highly regarded
Lord Chancellor and Law Lord, having previously

4088.26.text:
been Lord Advocate in Margaret Thatcher's
government. More recently still, Lord Rodger

4092.91.text:
of Earlsferry was a highly regarded Law Lord
and then Justice of the Supreme Court, having

4098.01.text:
previously been Lord Advocate in the John
Major administration. Indeed some commentators

4103.79.text:
would suggest that it can be desirable for
the senior judiciary to include at least some

4109.06.text:
judges who have previous experience of government
and the legislature, in the light of the important

4115.95.text:
constitutional questions which judges sometimes
have to decide. This does not compromise the

4122.63.text:
principle of independence, provided there
is a separation of powers at the time when

4128.82.text:
they are serving judges. Judges must relinquish
any links they may have had with a political

4136.40.text: party on their appointment to the bench.

4142.30.text:
I would like to end with a few concluding
remarks. Clearly the United States and the

4149.84.text:
United Kingdom have a long and shared commitment
to constitutionalism. However, the structural

4156.85.text:
differences between the two constitutional
systems mean that it is difficult to prune

4162.51.text:
principles from one legal system and simply
transplant them to the very different soil

4169.17.text:
of the other. Sometimes we use the same phrases,
such as "separation of powers" and "due process"

4178.09.text:
but these can be false friends, as their meaning
may be quite different in the two countries.

4185.42.text:
Having said that, the two systems have clearly
influenced each other too and continue to

4191.04.text:
do so, as in the field of freedom of speech.
Looking at the jurisprudence of the US can

4199.28.text:
be helpful in providing useful insights into
the way in which a problem is analysed, even

4207.84.text:
if the answer would not necessarily be the
same. It can also, quite simply, be enjoyable

4216.60.text:
for the "constitutional poetry" one can find
there.
